Eisenhower Talk
Dr. Eisenhower's first address to the University showed
promise for a fine period of interim leadership. His actions in
opening up the Board of Trustees to younger and more diverse
views seen in the election of the four new Board members are
worthy of our enthusiastic applause. In addition, the interim
president's genuine concern for the undergraduate is apparent
and his support for more teaching and more undergraduate
courses is quite welcome. But, according to the president's
speech, there will soon be 600 more undergraduates taking
these courses. It is imperative that the increase in courses
comes before the increase in students or the quality of the
undergraduate program will continue to decline. Now, we
have a president asking a faculty to increase their teaching
load, but if that request does not become reality, neither
should the increase in students, or we might find ourselves
with 600 bodies who have no place to go but the back of Rem sen
1. Apparently they won't even be able to go to an interim
student union, a fact that will not aid in attracting 600 more
quality students to an admittedly drab city.
The election of the new members to the Board could also fail
to realize its full promise. If these new Trustees are to be more
than novelties then they should be treated with the same
respect as the others and have a meaningful opportunity to
shape University policies. Serious consideration, then, should
be given to placing the new members on the most important
committees of the Board, including the Executive Committee.
If Dr. Eisenhower is truly interested in having diverse views
enter into the running of the University, perhaps he could see
what he can do about getting some current students on the
Academic Council.
For improving the undergraduate program, Dr. Eisenhower
is putting his faith in a graduate-oriented senior faculty.
Seemingly they have promised some substantive changes. But
let us hope that their graduate orientation does make these
changes a one-shot deal, that will fade as soon as the current
cooperative spirit wanes. Only a forceful effort by Dr.
Eisenhower, comparable to the dynamic achievement of his
previous tenure, will ensure that this is not the case.

Wickwire Courses
Dr. Chester Wickwire went before the Academic Council the
other day to defend his social action courses, which had been
attacked by the Zdanis Committee on Non-Departmental
Courses and other faculty members. Wickwire's critics say
that his courses lack proper academic content, and that there
is an absence of supervision in the field courses. Wickwire
presented to the senior scholars of the Council authoritative
evidence of the new scholarly approaches from the reports of
three educational commissions. "What they are saying," he
told them, "is that there are other ways to teach besides
having the student and teacher on opposite sides of the desk."
We urge the Academic Council in their deliberations next week
to consider the precedents set by other fine institutions, the
wishes of the Hopkins community and the importance of the
Wickwire courses. These urban-involvement courses are a
most valuable addition to the Hopkins academic program and
they should be preserved.
Wickwire's four undergraduate courses offer a unique
academic experience at least as valid as the other courses on
the Homewood program. In addition, they have vital field
programs which translate their learning into the reality of
social action. The 1500 members of the normally apathetic
Hopkins community who signed a petition supporting Wickwire should not be ignored merely because the Academic
Council members have a more arcahic view of what
scholarship should be.

Eisenhower Talk
Dr. Eisenhower's first address to the University showed
promise for a fine period of interim leadership. His actions in
opening up the Board of Trustees to younger and more diverse
views seen in the election of the four new Board members are
worthy of our enthusiastic applause. In addition, the interim
president's genuine concern for the undergraduate is apparent
and his support for more teaching and more undergraduate
courses is quite welcome. But, according to the president's
speech, there will soon be 600 more undergraduates taking
these courses. It is imperative that the increase in courses
comes before the increase in students or the quality of the
undergraduate program will continue to decline. Now, we
have a president asking a faculty to increase their teaching
load, but if that request does not become reality, neither
should the increase in students, or we might find ourselves
with 600 bodies who have no place to go but the back of Rem sen
1. Apparently they won't even be able to go to an interim
student union, a fact that will not aid in attracting 600 more
quality students to an admittedly drab city.
The election of the new members to the Board could also fail
to realize its full promise. If these new Trustees are to be more
than novelties then they should be treated with the same
respect as the others and have a meaningful opportunity to
shape University policies. Serious consideration, then, should
be given to placing the new members on the most important
committees of the Board, including the Executive Committee.
If Dr. Eisenhower is truly interested in having diverse views
enter into the running of the University, perhaps he could see
what he can do about getting some current students on the
Academic Council.
For improving the undergraduate program, Dr. Eisenhower
is putting his faith in a graduate-oriented senior faculty.
Seemingly they have promised some substantive changes. But
let us hope that their graduate orientation does make these
changes a one-shot deal, that will fade as soon as the current
cooperative spirit wanes. Only a forceful effort by Dr.
Eisenhower, comparable to the dynamic achievement of his
previous tenure, will ensure that this is not the case.

Wickwire Courses
Dr. Chester Wickwire went before the Academic Council the
other day to defend his social action courses, which had been
attacked by the Zdanis Committee on Non-Departmental
Courses and other faculty members. Wickwire's critics say
that his courses lack proper academic content, and that there
is an absence of supervision in the field courses. Wickwire
presented to the senior scholars of the Council authoritative
evidence of the new scholarly approaches from the reports of
three educational commissions. "What they are saying," he
told them, "is that there are other ways to teach besides
having the student and teacher on opposite sides of the desk."
We urge the Academic Council in their deliberations next week
to consider the precedents set by other fine institutions, the
wishes of the Hopkins community and the importance of the
Wickwire courses. These urban-involvement courses are a
most valuable addition to the Hopkins academic program and
they should be preserved.
Wickwire's four undergraduate courses offer a unique
academic experience at least as valid as the other courses on
the Homewood program. In addition, they have vital field
programs which translate their learning into the reality of
social action. The 1500 members of the normally apathetic
Hopkins community who signed a petition supporting Wickwire should not be ignored merely because the Academic
Council members have a more arcahic view of what
scholarship should be.

There are times of special
delight in every sport that
show how the human efforts
of athletes can be outstanding. There are countless
stories of how an athlete may
be injored and still play.
The Baltimore Bullets are
showing just how far a team
can go when injured. The
Bullets, without their all-star
forward
Gus
Johnson,
without super-sub Eddie
Miles, and without the services of starting guard Kevin
Loughery blew the New York
Knicks out of the Civic Center
twice.
The Knicks came to
Baltimore last weekend with
a two game to nothing lead in
the best-of-seven Eastern
Division Championship. They
return to New York tied at
two games apiece.
The Bullets, who had been
without Miles and Johnson in
the first two games, also lost
the services of Loughery, who
had injured his heel on
Sunday, while he saw limited

action Wednesday. The
Bullets were down to eight
minimum
players, the
number allowed in the
National Basketball
Association.
The starting lineup contained two players who had
been used solely as substitutes throughout the
season. Possibly the Knicks
just weren't up for the game,
maybe Willis Reed's injuries
were more serious than
imagined; these are only
speculations.
The truth is that the Bullets
knew that they could not get
into foul trouble, they knew
they all had to hve good
nights, and moreover they
knew that if they lost, they
were probably out of the
playoffs.
The last two years the
Knicks have played the
Bullets in the playoffs. Two
years ago, the Bullets'
'Cinderella' season when they
jumped from last place to
first place in one season, the
Knicks destroyed the Bullets

four games to none.
Last year, the Bullets faced
the Knicks again in the
Eastern Division Finals. The
Knicks jumped to a two to
nothing lead before the
Bullets came alive in the
third game. The Bullets then
forced the Knicks to go to
seven games before bowing
out. This year the Bullets
again came alive in the third
game.
It is impossible to speculate
why athletes can sometimes
come back from incredible
odds to do better than anyone
imagined. One thinks of the
time that Johnny Unitas and
Gary Guozzo were injured
and Tom Matte, the Colt
halfback had to quarterback
in the championships against
Los Angeles with the plays
written out on his sleeve. The
list goes on.
No matter how the playoffs
come out, one thing is sure,
the Bullets played well, in fact.
better than they ever played
during the season when
everyone was healthy.
